awd_titl_txt: Mechanical signal transduction and growth control: role of osmoregulation and cell wall extensibility
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will analyze how plants sense and adjust to their mechanical environment. Plants constantly experience mechanical challenges such as wind, heavy rain or dense soils. Many plants respond to these challenges by developing thicker, shorter stems and by tuning the architecture of their root systems for enhanced stability and strength. In crop plants, such responses play an important role in determining yield. To improve plant growth under adverse mechanical conditions, it is essential to understand how plants perceive mechanical challenges and how they translate this information into appropriate developmental responses. This project will analyze how the activity of plant membrane proteins is coordinated to modulate the mechanical properties of plant cells and organs in response to mechanical challenges. Understanding such processes should be of practical value in engineering more resilient and robust agricultural crops. Furthermore, tools will be developed that will enable researchers to identify which cells in a plant experience mechanical stresses under different growth conditions. Finally, this project will provide training opportunities in modern molecular biology and microscopy techniques for a postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students. It also includes effective hands-on investigation of original hypotheses by large numbers of students while introducing high school students to molecular biology research and techniques. 

Cellular perception of mechanical stress is a key element of growth control in plants. Mechanical forces associated with turgor pressure are harnessed to drive cellular expansion while mechanical cues imposed by the environment typically cause a reduction in cell elongation. The principal investigator's laboratory has identified the receptor-like kinase FERONIA as both a key regulator of mechanical Ca2+ signaling and a control element of cell expansion and growth responses to environmental mechanical challenges. A major research goal is to identify targets of FERONIA-dependent signaling and to understand how these signaling components impact cell expansion. To this end imaging-based tools will be developed to quantify rapid cellular osmoregulation, determine changes in viscoelastic properties of cell walls, and characterize the distribution and magnitude of mechanical signaling patterns in living tissues. This research aims to provide insight into the molecular mechanisms of mechanical signal transduction, identify strategies to enhance plant mechanical strength and provide the means to monitor mechanical stress in situ during plant development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plants exist in a mechanically challenging environment that affects growth and development at levels of organization ranging from individual cells to the entire plant body. Some of these mechanical forces are generated internally, for example in cells that experience high hydrostatic pressure, while other mechanical challenges are imposed externally by abiotic or biotic stresses. Many such mechanical stimuli are known to trigger a rapid change in the concentration of the cellular regulator calcium as the first detectable response to mechanosensation.  By combining cell biology, automated phenotyping, biochemistry, genetic screens and transcriptional analyses, this research program has sought to (i) define the molecular machinery generating calcium signals, (ii) determine whether the particular shape of calcium signals (the calcium signature) modulates transcriptional responses to mechanical challenges, (iii) elucidate how calcium signals are converted into immediate growth inhibition, and (iv) characterize the relationship between calcium signaling and the cellular fate of candidate mechano-receptors in the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana.

Mechanical stretching of plant cells by bending or osmotic downshock triggers a complex change in calcium levels which can be separated into two phases requiring distinct sets of calcium transporters. By visualizing cytosolic calcium levels with the fluorescent calcium reporter Yellow Cameleon 3.6, we identified members of the cyclic nucleotide-gated channel family (CNGC6 and CNGC14) as being required for generating the second phase of the cytosolic calcium increase. Loss of CNGC6 and CNGC14 reduced the ability of Arabidopsis roots to penetrate compacted growth media, suggesting that mutant roots are weakened.

Osmotic downshock, which causes water to immediately flow into and thereby stretch cells, triggers a rapid change in gene expression. RNA sequencing assays showed that over 50% of genes induced by osmotic downshock were upregulated in a calcium-dependent manner. A subset of those genes were clearly sensitive to the altered calcium signature in cngc6 and -14 mutants, such that loss of the second phase of the biphasic calcium elevation substantially reduced the extent of gene upregulation.  We developed fluorescent markers to investigate the dynamics of mechanical transcriptional responses in real time at cellular resolution in intact plants.

Environmental stresses can cause inhibition of plant growth, as cells responsible for such growth undergo a rapid and often drastic reduction in expansion rates. We found that such growth inhibition is dependent on calcium signaling and is mediated by stimulus-specific mechanisms including the loss of cell hydrostatic pressure (turgor) through rapid osmoregulation.

To appropriately tune the duration and intensity of plant responses to environmental stresses, control mechanisms need to be in place to modulate receptor-mediated signaling.  Fluorescence microscopy and protein biochemistry approaches revealed that the candidate mechano-receptor FERONIA undergoes distinct, but calcium-dependent processing in different signaling contexts. 

Overall, this research project has confirmed the central role of calcium signaling in plant responses to mechanical challenges, identified ion channels that contribute to signal production, revealed novel mechanisms of growth inhibition via osmoregulation, and addressed long-standing questions about the ability of plants to convert distinct calcium signatures into signature-specific responses.

As part of our educational and outreach activities, we developed computational tools to support high-resolution growth analyses, developed a set of fluorescent-timer marker lines to visualize the dynamics of mechanical signal transduction in Arabidopsis, trained four undergraduate students, one MS student and three PhD students, and provided  independent research opportunities to over 90 undergraduate students to improve scientific literacy.
